title: Three Point Charges Arranged in a Line

content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Three point charges of equal magnitudes but different signs are arranged in a line as shown. The distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between each charge is the same. Point X is exactly halfway between the two positive charges, and point Y is exactly halfway between the negative charge and the positive charge in the middle of the line.

(a) Compare the magnitude of the electric field at point X to the magnitude of the electric field at point Y. Justify your answer.

This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Three point charges of equal magnitudes but different signs are arranged in a line as shown. The distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between each charge is the same. Point X is exactly halfway between the two positive charges, and point Y is exactly halfway between the negative charge and the positive charge in the middle of the line.

(a) Compare the magnitude of the electric field at point X to the magnitude of the electric field at point Y. Justify your answer.

Consider two scenarios, one in which an individual proton is moved from far away to point X, and the other in which an individual proton is moved from far away to point Y.
(b) An external force must do non-zero work to move the proton to point X. Indicate whether the work is positive or negative. Justify your answer using the concepts of electric fields or forces.

(c) The work required to move an individual proton from far away to point X is <math alttext="W sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The work required to move an individual proton from far away to point Y is <math alttext="W sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Compare the magnitudes of <math alttext="W sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="W sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer using the concept of electric potential.

When a proton with a charge of magnitude <math alttext="e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is brought from far away to either point X or point Y, the proton-charges system experiences a change in potential energy of magnitude <math alttext="delta U sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Expressions that represent the change in potential energy as a proton is brought from far away to either point X or point Y are given below.
Expression 1          Expression 2<math alttext="delta U equals, the fraction with numerator 2 k, times e, times Q, and denominator 3 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>k</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="delta U equals, the fraction with numerator 4 k, times e, times Q, and denominator d, end fraction, minus the fraction with numerator 2 k, times e, times Q, and denominator 3 d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>k</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>k</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>
(d) Which expression represents the change in potential energy <math alttext="delta U sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer using physics principles.
(e) Is your answer from part (d) consistent with your answer from part (c)? Justify your answer using physics principles.

Two point charges, M and N, have the charges shown in the figure above. Each charge is a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> due to charge M has magnitude <math alttext="E sub M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) Describe the magnitude and direction of the net electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> due to both charges in terms of <math alttext="E sub M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and with respect to the coordinate axes shown. If the net electric field is not directed along an axis, indicate to which axis the direction of the net electric field is closest. If the direction of the net electric field is exactly in the middle (<math alttext="45 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from each axis), state this explicitly. Explain your reasoning using relevant physics principles.
(g) The diagrams shown above depict isolines of electric potential. Which diagram best depicts the isolines of electric potential of charges M and N? Explain your reasoning.
